title: How I Finally Memorized Modifier Ordering in Compose
description: For the longest time, I proudly had no idea of how Modifier ordering works, and would just guess and then guess again when something didn't look quite right. Here's how I finally ended up remembering how the ordering works.
author: Márton Braun

title: Building a macOS screen saver in Kotlin
description: This article documents how I created my own custom screen saver for macOS, built almost entirely in Kotlin, using the powers of Kotlin Multiplatform compiled to macOS. Join me for a tale of Kotlin success and macOS failures.
author: Márton Braun

title: Episode 211: Rules about performance tools
description: In this episode Chet, Romain and Tor chat with Shai Barack about how the Android platform team studies performance and understands system health - and what is system health anyway? We talk about measuring performance, deciding trade-offs, and our favorite tools such as Perfetto, Compiler Explorer, and Android Studio's Memory Profiler.   Chapters: Intro (00:00) System health (0:27) Efforts to make apps more efficient (3:35) Telemetry data (5:59) Trade offs between long battery life and good performance (8:21) Scheduling groups (10:38) Static drain (13:32) Collaborating with App developers vs operating system (19:10) High refresh rates (23:26) Reach vs engagement (32:02) What tools does your team use to optimize performance? (34:10) Godbolt.org (37:09) Demystifying (39:39) The best tools are multi-player (43:52) R8 or R-Not? (45:42) Optimizing for feature sets (48:05) Tools, not Rules (50:08) What are the tools I should be aware of as an app developer looking to upscale performance? (54:36) Allocation tracker (55:37) Open source tools (57:08) Useful resources for devs to understand various tools (59:04) Final thoughts (1:06:19) Links: Compiler Explorer → https://goo.gle/3Zbq6DV  Perfetto → https://goo.gle/3OtD3UK and https://goo.gle/3B3S3p5  Tools, not Rules  → https://goo.gle/416CyY7    Shai:  Romain: @romainguy, threads.net/@romainguy, romainguy@androiddev.social Tor: threads.net/@tor.norbye and tornorbye@androiddev.social Chet: @chethaase, threads.net/@chet.haase, and chethaase@androiddev.social   Catch videos on YouTube → https://goo.gle/adb-podcast   Subscribe to Android Developers  → https://goo.gle/AndroidDevs
author: Android Developers

title: Episode 210: Studio Jewelry
description: In this episode Chet, Romain and Tor chat with Sebastiano about how the Android Studio team builds UIs. We talk about how Compose for Desktop is used in parts of Android Studio and how the Compose Markdown renderer available in the Jewel library makes Studio Bot tick.   Chapters: Intro (00:00) Android Dev UX team (00:39) What kind of libraries and languages are used to build Android studio? (1:52) Swing (2:53) Reactive and declarative programming models (8:25) SKIA for Kotlin (10:01) Jetpack Compose widgets (11:54) Jewel (13:07) Text rendering across platforms (15:51) Differences in behaviors (17:40) Support for markdown files (20:26) What is markdown? (21:25) Swing and html (25:45) Selection handling in StudioBot (28:46) Boosting productivity with Compose (30:40) Standalone vs plugin artifacts (34:29) The difference between Jewel & Swing (35:30) HTML vs Markdown (39:31) Markdeep (41:53) Jewel's Markdown API (43:46) Where to find Jewel? (46:54) Sebastiano’s podcast - Code with the Italians (47:34) Final thoughts (49:13)   Links: Jetpack Compose Compose Multiplatform, for Desktop  Jewel Jewel Markdown Renderer   Sebastiano: ​​https://github.com/rock3r, https://codewiththeitalians.it/ Romain: @romainguy, threads.net/@romainguy, romainguy@androiddev.social Tor: threads.net/@tor.norbye and tornorbye@androiddev.social Chet: @chethaase, threads.net/@chet.haase, and chethaase@androiddev.social   Catch videos on YouTube → https://goo.gle/adb-podcast   Subscribe to Android Developers  → https://goo.gle/AndroidDevs

title: 253 - logcat - a new look at logging with Piwai from Square
description: Kaushik looks at a new logging library from Square called logcat. He starts by seeing how the popular Timber library does it along with the benefits. He then interviews Pierre-Yves Ricau (Piwai) of Square, the creator of logcat, to explore its origins and advantages.You can find the full shownotes over at fragmentedpodcast.com.Show NotesTimberlogcatMotivations in READMECompiler plugin issuePlayground android app demonstrating logcatbitdrift.ioDesign of everyday thingsPrevious episode #191 on loggingContact Piwai:WebsiteBlueskyContactYou can find us on a few places:fragmentedpodcast.comContact usYoutubeKaushik:kau.sh (links to everything)ThreadsBlueskyYoutube@kaushikgopalDisclaimer: Links shared might be affiliate links. They help support the production of Fragmented. Thank you for your support.
author: Pierre-Yves Ricau, Kaushik Gopal

title: 252 - Everyone needs a starter template
description: In this episode of Fragmented, Kaushik dives into the importance of creating your own starter template to streamline app development and minimize decision fatigue. He shares insights from his own starter template - Playground Android.Looking to the future, JetBrains has an exciting tool called Amper that might make all of this much easier. Kaushik chats with JetBrains’ Márton Braun about Amper, an exciting new tool that could revolutionize Kotlin & Android project setups.Tune in to learn how to go from idea to code with less friction!You can find the full shownotes over at fragmentedpodcast.com.Show NotesPlayground AndroidThe Architecture Templates (blog post)Inspiration (Other starter templates):Bloco's starter template what i referenced a lotDonn's project - Jumpstart Android if you care about quickly getting a Rails app integrated with Android in a hybrid experienceNow in Android too much functionality for my tasteJake's u2020 for some good times nostalgiaPlayground Androidgradle version catalog - BOM & Bundles (one source of truth)sharing build logic with gradle convention pluginMakefile with common cli commandsCustom lint-rulesMulti module setupdependency injection with kotlin-inject-anvilEpisode 251 - There's a new king in DI townfunction-injection demo in @ComposableAmperlogcat lib and injecting multiple loggersbasic networking with ktor #10compose-navigation between feature modulesIury's post on Kotlin DevexAmperblog posts on AmperFeedback on Amper - kotlinlang slackContact Márton BraunContactYou can find us on a few places:fragmentedpodcast.comYoutubeKaushik:kau.sh (links to everything)Bluesky@kaushikgopalThreadsYoutubeDisclaimer: Links shared might be affiliate links. They help support the production of Fragmented. Thank you for your support.
author: Márton Braun, Kaushik Gopal

title: Android Weekly Issue #653
description: Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Genius Scan SDK: a document scanner in your app Embed a reliable document scanner with OCR in your app, enabling your customers to capture high-quality, legible documents that you can process effortlessly. Hundreds of companies and millions of users trust the Genius Scan technology. Supports Android, iOS, and cross-platform frameworks. Debugging Kotlin in Xcode with SPM Builds Kevin Galligan writes about how Touchlab fixed debugging Kotlin Multiplatform code in Xcode. Let’s build an Android camera app! CameraX + Compose Tom Colvin builds a camera app with a preview use case, selfie/rear camera selection, zoom, and image capture, using CameraX. Sponsored Get started with OpenTelemetry for Android In this tutorial, learn how to integrate the OpenTelemetry SDK for Android and start collecting observability data. Instrument spans with attributes and attach metadata to the resources object to address network latency issues, OS version or device-specific issues, and unexpected user behavior. SDK Development; The Good, The Bad, The Ugly Through a decade of working with SDKs, Javad Arjmandi has seen the good, the bad, and the downright ugly when it comes to SDKs. Understanding ViewModel Persistence Across Configuration Changes Sandeep Kella dive deep into the mechanics and internal implementation of the ViewModel system to understand persistence across configuration changes. Automate Android Feature Creation with Gradle Learn how to streamline the process of generating files with reusable templates using a Gradle Task. Koin’s Isolated Context Stefano Natali shows how to create a separate dependency injection container for your libraries and SDKs. Koin IDE Plugin: A Koin Configuration Tree Art Shendrik shares a sneak peek of the Koin IDE Plugin currently under development and targeting Q1 2025. Reddit improved app startup speed using Baseline Profiles and R8 An overview of how the Reddit team optimized its Android app to reduce startup times and improve rendering performance using Baseline Profiles Adaptive Layouts in Compose Multiplatform Kevin Schildhorn looks at adaptive layouts for adapting your UI to fit different display sizes on Android, and it's now available for Compose Multiplatform. You Are Going to Need It Romain Guy focuses on one of the (numerous) benchmarking traps encountered regularly. LLM Based Android UI Testing – “Journeys with Gemini” Sam Edwards takes a closer look at LLM-based Android UI testing. Google Maps in Jetpack Compose: Polygons Joe Birch dives into the Polygon composable and learn how we can draw coordinate-based shapes on our map. Place a sponsored post Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers We reach out to more than 80k Android developers around the world, every week, through our email newsletter and social media channels. Advertise your Android development course! Jobs Senior Android Engineer (New York, NY) Behance gives creatives everything they need to showcase their work, find opportunities, and get paid. You will join an agile team of mobile engineers shipping native apps, quickly integrating new technologies like Jetpack Compose, and shepherding the Adobe app ecosystem into the future. Libraries & Code logcat A tiny Kotlin API for cheap logging on top of Android's normal Log class. News The next chapter of the Gemini era for developers Google announced Gemini 2.0 Flash Experimental to enable even more immersive and interactive applications, as well as new coding agents that will enhance workflows by taking action on behalf of the developer. Notes from Google Play: The next phase of Play Google shares a vision for the next phase of Play where Play leans into being more than a store and becomes a dynamic platform that connects people with your content. Introducing Android XR SDK Developer Preview Google has launched the developer preview of the Android XR SDK - a comprehensive development kit for Android XR. Videos & Podcasts Modularization of large Android apps Lajos Nyéki explores the challenges faced in large Android applications, including longer build times and coordination issues among multiple development teams. Top 3 Custom Loading Animations In Jetpack Compose Philipp Lackner shows 3 cool custom loading animations you can implement with Jetpack Compose. Building a Clean Architecture App using MVVM & Jetpack Compose Daniel Atitienei shows you how to build a Clean Architecture app based on League of Legends. Notes from Google Play: The next phase of Play Sam Bright takes a look back at some of the key features and programs launched this year to help you build successful apps and games businesses. logcat - a new look at logging with Piwai from Square Kaushik looks at a new logging library from Square called logcat. Remind users to Rate your App - Compose Multiplatform Remind users to Rate your App - Compose Multiplatform Android 16 Developer Preview 1, Passkeys Spotlight Week, and more! Learn more about the First Developer Preview of Android 16, Spotlight Week on Passkeys, Stability and Performance Improvements to the Android Emulator and more! Expanding Jewel: Markdown-to-Compose Magic In this live-coding episode, Ivan and Seb roll up their sleeves and dive into Jewel, adding new features to its Markdown-to-Compose rendering engine. Going from Swift to Kotlin with Skip Sebastian and Márton talk to the founders of Skip, an iOS-to-Android, Swift-to-Kotlin transpiler solution. Specials Start More Projects Whether you think you’ll be able to finish them or not, Ryan Harter thinks you should start more projects.

title: Android Weekly Issue #652
description: Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Add paywalls in one line of code Take the pain out of configuring and testing your app's paywalls. With RevenueCat Paywalls you can remotely configure and edit your entire paywall view without waiting on App Review. The pursuit of fast feedback loops in Android development Saket Narayan shares some suggestions to find your fast feedback loops. Implementing Live Camera OCR with Jetpack Compose Anil Kumar Beesetti explores how to implement a live camera view with OCR in Jetpack Compose. Sponsored Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers We reach out to more than 80k Android developers around the world, every week, through our email newsletter and social media channels. Advertise your Android development course! 5 steps to implement MVI architecture with Jetpack Compose Anitaa Murthy worked on a simple Notes app recently to get to understand MVI architecture a bit more and shares the approach. Screenshot testing in Jetpack Compose Oliver Vicente introduces a useful tool for screenshot testing in Jetpack Compose. How easy is drag-and-drop in Compose? Mustafa Khaled shows how implementing a drag-and-drop feature is now easier in Compose. Four Tips to Help You Build High-Quality, Engaging, and Age-Appropriate Apps Google shares some important reminders and updates on how we empower developers to build high-quality, engaging, and age-appropriate apps across the Android ecosystem. Vulkan 1.4: Faster app loads, less stutter and less Memory Usage Shahbaz Youssefi looks at why the latest Vulkan Host Image Copy is a game changer for Android. UI State, Callbacks and Equality Pitfalls Stojan Anastasov explores why using function properties in data classes is problematic, particularly for maintaining equality. How to add platform-specific icons to a Compose Multiplatform project Alex Zhukovich explores how to support platform-specific icons in Compose Multiplatform project. Compose Animation, Under The Hood - Part II In this second part, Sagar Viradiya explores how the Compose Animation system was built on top of Animation API. Using BlockHound to track blocking calls in non-blocking dispatchers Marcin Moskała shows how to use BlockHound to track blocking calls in Kotlin Coroutines non-blocking dispatchers. Animated Text Field Hint in Jetpack Compose sinasamaki shows how to build a playful text field hint animation. Testing Different Navigation Options with Compose Eevis Panula share some examples of how to write tests for several different styles of navigation. Jobs Change how the world learns at Brilliant.org (Remote, NYC, and SF) Engineers at Brilliant think about both “building the right thing” AND “building the thing right” while pursuing high standards of excellence for ourselves, our users, and our codebase. 💰 $180k - $225k. Join us! Senior Android Engineer (London/UK Remote) As a Senior Android Engineer at Treecard, you'll be at the forefront of shaping our cutting-edge mobile experiences. Expect your days to be filled with dynamic challenges, as you are part of a team dedicated to the delivery of features that truly matter. Libraries & Code Passage Passage is a Kotlin Multiplatform library designed to simplify authentication flows across Android and iOS platforms. News Introducing PaliGemma 2: Powerful Vision-Language Models, Simple Fine-Tuning PaliGemma 2 builds upon the performant Gemma 2 models, adding the power of vision and making it easier than ever to fine-tune for exceptional performance Making the Play Integrity API faster, more resilient, and more private Google shares how they're enhancing the Play Integrity API for everyone. User-Agent Reduction on Android WebView Beginning in Android 16, the default User-Agent string in Android WebView will be similarly reduced. KMMBridge 1.1.0 Released Kevin Galligan announces the 1.1.0 release, a significant internal refactoring to support ongoing improvements and maintainability. Videos & Podcasts UUID in Kotlin Multiplatform Marton Braun examines the use of UUIDs in Kotlin Multiplatform. Hot Reloading Compose Apps with ClassLoaders (Firework Experiment) Sebastian Sellmair explains the first attempt of implementing Hot Reload for Compose Applications: ClassLoaders. How to Create a One-Time Password TextField in Jetpack Compose Philipp Lackner shows how you can implement a 4-digit one-time password input text field with Jetpack Compose. How to Manage Run-Time Permissions in Android and iOS Learn how to manager runtime permissions with Compose Multiplatform. Immutable and Persistent Lists - TypeAlias Show Clip Dave Leeds looks at the kotlinx.collections.immutable library in this clip from a livestream. Playtime EMEA 2024 All the presentations from Google's Playtime EMEA 2024 Hot Reload Magic with Márton Braun—Discover Firework in Action! Code with the Italians for an explosive episode as we sit down with Márton Braun, Developer Advocate at JetBrains, to explore Firework, a groundbreaking tool that brings hot reload capabilities to Compose

description: An easy implementation for the use of the camera and gallery, customized according to your needs.

title: SimpleCamera
description: Simple Camera is a library that allows you to use cameras in a simplified, easy, fast and effective way. It contains CameraX as an internal library. It simplifies the camera features used by CameraX and provides ease of use with a single library. As updates come on the CameraX side, the library will try to stay up to date. Missing features will be added soon. Like video capturing.

title: Testing safe area insets on iOS
description: I’m adding edge-to-edge UI support in Redwood. My code asks the host platform how much of the screen is consumed by system bars and notches and things, and it returns us a measurement like ‘40 pixels at the top + 10 pixels at the bottom’.The iOS code to handle

title: EML viewer tools for different platforms
description: In the digital age, where email communication is paramount, handling various email formats becomes essential. Among these formats, EML (Email Message Format) files are widely used. EML files contain email messages and attachments, and viewing them efficiently across different platforms can be a challenge. This article explores the diverse landscape of EML viewer tools available for different platforms, aiding users in seamlessly accessing and managing their email content. The post EML viewer tools for different platforms appeared first on Universal Accessibility.
author: admgoobar

title: Viewing attachments in EML files
description: In the digital age, email communication plays a pivotal role in both personal and professional spheres. The exchange of information often involves attachments, which enhance the message’s content and functionality. Among the various file formats used in email correspondence, EML files are prominent. Understanding how to view attachments within EML files is essential for efficient... The post Viewing attachments in EML files appeared first on Universal Accessibility.

title: Building a sub-sampling image viewer for Compose UI
description: How do you display a 100mb image on Android without running into OutOfMemoryError? You can’t. But you can cheat. For years Android developers have used Dave Morrissey’s excellent library, subsampling-scale-image-view for displaying large bitmaps with deep zoom. It optimizes memory usage by loading lower resolution bitmaps whenever possible and avoiding loading parts of the original […] The post Building a sub-sampling image viewer for Compose UI appeared first on Saket Narayan.
